_exec_summary.SummaryText:
WESTERN PRECOOLING SYSTEMS/MOUNTAIN VIEW DIVISION



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN LEVEL III - 5 Year Update & Re-submittal 2019



1 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.

1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances.

1.3 Summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

1.4 Summary of the Five-Year Accident History.

1.5 Summary of the Emergency Response Program.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Western Precooling Systems/Mountain View Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies. The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs. Company safety programs include but are not limited to a comprehensive & Process Safety Management Program (PSM), which is an integrated approach to Accidental Release Prevention & the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances. The PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen. It is the goal of the company to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations.



A "Non Responding Facility" policy has been adopted; however the Company recognizes the need to be prepared to safely deal with emergencies. A Hazardous Material Business Plan consistent with Emergency Action Plan requirements has been developed and includes emergency procedures, requirements, and information necessary to notify public response agencies and technical resources; the Staff communicate to the Fire Department and evacuate (or shelter-in-place) if there is a release situation or fire. Managers and employees would also shepherd visitors (truck drivers receiving product or delivering product). By effectiv

ely determining all persons are safe, the Fire Department can more swiftly manage the tactical part of a response. It is the policy of the company that no-one shall respond to an emergency in a way that is beyond his or her level of training and responsibility.



The facility is supported by Western Precooling Systems (WPS) for ammonia refrigeration maintenance needs. The WPS Oxnard regional office is within ? mile of the site. WPS supports HAZWOPER 1910.120 (q) and Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians (RETA) training for key Refrigerating Technicians and management personnel. These personnel are available to support Oxnard Fire/CUPA and the facility in the event of an emergency, and staff are on-call 24/7/365. Written procedures that include ammonia specific emergency pre-planning have been developed within the WPS "Thirty Minute Plan". Ammonia-specific emergency equipment is maintained in WPS Refrigerating Technician's service vehicles. The company strives to execute its accidental release prevention & emergency response policies through appropriately skilled employees that are provided with adequate equipment and training.



A relationship with Oxnard Fire/CUPA has been established. Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated via regular site visits/inspections and submittal of appropriate EPCRA and other compliance reports. Compliance reports and submittals are updated in accordance with applicable requirements at predetermined intervals. Oxnard Fire/CUPA has also participated with WPS in the execution of Process Hazard Analysis at this and other facilities in the Oxnard area. The WPS/Mountain View Division facility has confirmed that it is included in the Oxnard Community Emergency Plan, and key management personnel have received Incident Command System (ICS) training.



1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The WPS/Mt. View Cooler is located in Oxnard, CA; in a commercial/industrial area of the city. The facility

was constructed in 2013 and began operating in March 2014. Facility building space occupies approximately 102,000 square feet on a 5.5 acre lot; 67,636 square feet is devoted to refrigerated warehouse space. The refrigeration process is a state-of-the-art system engineered and installed according to the current codes and standards adopted locally by the City of Oxnard. Cutting-edge safety controls are engineered directly into the plant including but not limited to the Ammonia Control, Monitoring, Detection and Alarm System; and new Fire Suppression System including sprinkled building space. The Mountain View Division is 100% owned by Western Precooling Systems. The Mountain View Division manages pre-cooling and refrigerated storage; Western Precooling Systems supervises & maintains the refrigeration system.



The facility provides refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested fruit (pre-cooling strawberries, blueberries, raspberries and blackberries) and then subsequent short-term refrigerated storage prior to shipping. The berries are on site generally from 1-4 days from harvesting depending on market demand. The facility is seasonally operated with product harvest periods picking up in the month of November and finishing in July. The remaining months see little fresh product, however the refrigeration equipment is still operative. Major maintenance is performed in the off-season. Operational maintenance is performed on a year-round basis. Company policy requires appropriately pre-qualified personnel to perform maintenance tasks.



The Regulated Substance in use is Anhydrous Ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, which is used in a single closed-loop mechanical refrigeration system. Refrigeration equipment consists of Compressors, Condensers, Vessels, Pumps, Mobile and Stationary Pressure Cooling Units, Room Evaporators, piping and an Ammonia-water Diffusion System. Pressure and temperature controls are installed in accordance with appropriate stan

dards, including isolation and overpressure safety relief valves. The Ammonia-water Diffusion System protects the Safety Relief Valves from venting directly to atmosphere. An automated refrigeration control, monitoring and alarm system automatically monitors the system. The Alarm System is supervised 24/7/365 by a third party alarm company which maintains pre-determined call lists and parameters.



1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Accidental Release Prevention Program

The design of the refrigeration systems along with the implementation of the PSM Accidental Release Prevention Program is designed to provide assurance that the risks associated with the ammonia refrigerant are effectively managed. The elements of the PSM Program are intended to be integrated with the ongoing functions of the facility. The program is specifically intended to prevent an occurrence and minimize the consequences of an Anhydrous Ammonia release. In California the PSM program is in accordance with CCR 8, 5189, which is integrated with the Cal/ARP and Fed/ARP Accidental Release Prevention Programs.



Written procedures have been developed for the daily operation of ammonia-handling equipment, including the steps to be taken in the event of a release or threatened release. The written procedures include necessary safety precautions and address each operating phase as defined by the Cal-ARP RMP/PSM Program. Refrigeration systems are only operated by pre-qualified personnel that are trained and qualified in the relevant operating and safety procedures. The Written Operating Procedures are maintained on-site and regularly validated.



Scheduled inspections and maintenance are executed by Western Precooling Systems (WPS) qualified technicians and/or pre-qualified specialty vendors. WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA). WPS Technicia

ns participate in a state of the art online training program that includes RETA course materials (Web-based Business Manager/WBBM).



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Over the years it had become apparent in the Industry that a mishap while draining oil from the system was one of the most common release incidents to occur. Special self-closing valves are now installed as a permissive for oil drain flow. If a release were to develop during the oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated. The facility has installed these types of valves at each of the system's oil drain points.



Other ammonia-specific release prevention steps:

-Pressure relief valves are piped to a common header that terminates at the bottom of an Ammonia-Water Diffusion Tank.

-A computer monitoring system that monitors process parameters 24/7/365. This ammonia alarm system is continuously monitored via a third party security company.

-The monitoring system messages Technicians if the system approaches out-of-tolerance parameters.

-The facility is equipped with a Closed-Circuit TV (CCTV) System.

-The facility is fenced and gated to limit access by potential "wrong-do-ers".

-A sign-in/sign-out program is established per the PSM Program. Facility access is controlled.

-Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for un-authorized personnel, suspicious activity, fires, releases or other hazardous/suspicious condition.

-The facility strives to maintain a good working relationship with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA.

-Staff is trained in the fire and accident prevention benefits of good housekeeping. The general appearance of the facility is maintained on a day-to-day basis.

-An Auto-purger virtually eliminates manual purging of non-condensables.



1.4 Five-Year Accident History



There is no data to report.

1.5 The Emergency Response Program



This plant is specifically designed and engineered to pro

vide for life safety and effective emergency response. Building space is fire-alarm, ammonia alarm and fire-sprinkler equipped. The refrigeration process' Control, Monitoring and Alarm System includes a backup power supply (UPS) and manual backup systems (kill switches). The system initiates notifications, alarms, equipment shutdown and pump-down of the affected area according to the location, nature and severity of the problem. Authorized personnel can access critical process system controls remotely. The refrigeration process is equipped with a Fire Department Emergency Control Box and a KNOX is installed. The KNOX is kept up-to-date via communications with Oxnard Fire/CUPA. Automatic systems and devices are regularly inspected, tested and maintained. Employees are trained in manual discovery, emergency shutdown, evacuation and notification procedures in the highly unlikely event of a failure of the engineered safety and emergency systems.



The Plant does not require its employees to participate in conducting emergency response activities under the HAZWOPER standard; a "Non-responding Facility Policy" has been adopted for the Plant as a whole. In the event of an ammonia emergency, the response is to follow the procedures in the Equipment SOP's and the California Hazardous Material Business Plan. The overall procedure is to shutdown critical systems if it can be done safely by qualified personnel, evacuate, and notify the local response agencies and WPS; WPS employs technicians that are 1910.120(q) Hazardous Material Technician certified. Plant employees are to implement hazard communications, provide for the safety of visitors and report to the established Evacuation Staging Area(s) for a head count. Emergency response is coordinated with the City of Oxnard Fire/CUPA. The facility has confirmed that it is included in the Oxnard Community Emergency Plan required by the Emergency Planning and Community-Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  Oxnard Fire/CUPA performs routine
